title: curtis.txt
references: The document discusses the need for structural change in economic praxis and theory, comparing it to the fall of Marxist-Leninist central planning.
It mentions the importance of formalizing securities to stabilize markets and eliminate informal securities.
facts: The United States is facing a chronic national deficit and excessive borrowing across both public and private sectors.
The concept of 'restructuring' in a financial sense is equated to national bankruptcy.
The Federal Reserve System is part of the government and cannot run out of dollars.
A proper bankruptcy is described as a restructuring of accounting systems rather than a cessation of operations.
New sovereign accounting principles state that the government owns the country, fiat currency is government equity, and markets are stable when there are no informal securities.
habits: The US has been borrowing excessively for at least fifty years, funding consumption rather than genuine investment.
There is a lack of clarity between public and private financial responsibilities.
The existing financial system is referred to as 'American boomer finance,' which requires understanding before winding it down.
